description:
Laspeyria flexula, commonly known as the Straw Belle, is a species of moth belonging to the family Erebidae. It is a small moth, with a wingspan typically ranging from 20 to 25 millimeters.

The Straw Belle has a distinctive appearance, with its forewings being a pale straw-yellow color, often with a faint brownish tinge. The hindwings are a lighter, more translucent shade of yellow. The body of the moth is also pale in color, with a slender build.

This species is widely distributed across Europe, ranging from the Iberian Peninsula to Scandinavia and eastward to the Ural Mountains. It inhabits a variety of habitats, including deciduous forests, heathlands, and scrublands.

The Straw Belle is known to be attracted to light sources, and it is often observed resting on tree trunks or other surfaces during the day. Its flight period typically extends from June to August, with the larvae feeding on various herbaceous plants, including bedstraws and other members of the Rubiaceae family.

Overall, the Straw Belle is a relatively common and widespread moth species within its range, and it plays a role in the ecosystem as a pollinator and a food source for other organisms.
